english: a kind of war axe with three blades

etymology.description: 金(金) (jīn, "metal") + 奇(奇) (qí, "strange") = a metal object with unique features -> refers to a specific type of war axe
etymology.interpretation: 錡(錡) (qí) combines the metal radical 金(金), suggesting a metallic object, with the phonetic component 奇(奇), implying something uncommon or unique. This reflects the specialized nature of the weapon.
etymology.simplification: Simplified to 锜(锜) with 金(金, "metal") simplified to 钅(钅, "metal").

examples.chinese: 战士手中的錡发出寒光(戰士手中的錡發出寒光)。
examples.pinyin: Zhànshì shǒuzhōng de qí fāchū hán guāng.
examples.english: The warrior's three-bladed axe in his hand emitted a cold gleam.

examples.chinese: 古代战场上(古代戰場上)，三刃錡劈开敌阵(三刃錡劈開敵陣)。
examples.pinyin: Gǔdài zhànchǎng shàng, sān rèn qí pī kāi dí zhèn.
examples.english: On ancient battlefields, the three-bladed axe cleaved through enemy lines.

examples.chinese: 将军挥动錡在战场上(將軍揮動錡在戰場上)，鼓舞士气(鼓舞士氣)。
examples.pinyin: Jiāngjūn huīdòng qí zài zhànchǎng shàng, gǔwǔ shìqì.
examples.english: The general swung the three-bladed axe on the battlefield, inspiring his troops.
